name: Emma AOSE
comment info:
I immediately noticed how differently America’s population changed over the course of a decade compared to the top 10 largest countries, and the difference between what it means for an overall population to decrease, versus what it means when there is a decrease in population change. 

The top 10 countries had less population fluctuations compared to the United States. Between the years of 2011 and 2016, the population changes were fairly consistent; the U.S averaged an average increase of a little over 2 million people, while all other countries represented in this graph had an increase of approximately 500,000 people. What was the reasoning behind these differences? However, beginning in 2017, and in all the following years, there were drastic drops in population growth within America. 

What caused this rapid decline? Perhaps it was because of political, environmental, or socioeconomic concerns? In 2021, there was the biggest drop of the decade. Was this fueled by the increasing mortality rates from Covid-19, as well as the fears of another pandemic? Did prospective families fear what could happen in the future?

As an American, I wonder how these population changes will affect the economy. With less people, there might be too many job openings, thus, hurting the economy. 

Headline: The Decline of the Decade: U.S Population Change Drops

name: Nicole
comment info:
I noticed that from 2011 through 2016 the rate at which the U.S. population grew (i.e., increased from year to year) was fairly constant (not "consistent") at about 2 million people per year. But beginning in 2017, this rate of growth began decreasing significantly. However, over the same period from 2011 through 2021, the rate at which the population of the top ten counties was increasing remained fairly constant at about 350K - 400K people per year. I also noticed that by 2021, practically all of the growth in the U.S. the population was in the top ten counties, with very little growth in the rest of the country.

I wondered if there was a correlation between the election of President Trump and the decreasing population in 2017. I also wondered what happened in 2017 that could have "put the brakes on" population growth in the U.S. 

This relates to my community because It might affect my community depending on who moves in and who moves out. The decrease in our country over the years.

"Population change in the US on a rapid decline"

name: William Wroblicka
comment info:
I notice that from 2011 through 2016 the rate at which the U.S. population grew (i.e., increased from year to year) was fairly constant (not "consistent") at about 2 million+ people per year. But beginning in 2017, this rate of growth began decreasing significantly. However, over the same period from 2011 through 2021, the rate at which the population of the top ten counties was increasing remained fairly constant at about 350K - 400K people per year. I also notice that by 2021, practically all of the growth in the U.S. population was in the top ten counties, with very little growth in the rest of the country.

I wonder what happened in 2017 that could have "put the brakes on" population growth in the U.S. It was too early for Covid, but coincident with the election of President Trump. I wonder if it could have something to do with a decrease in the number of immigrants coming into the country. If so, the graph seems to indicate that the immigrants who did arrive during this period mostly settled in the top ten counties -- either that or the influx of immigrants into the greater U.S. more or less was matched by people moving from elsewhere into the top ten counties. Also I wonder if the especially big drop in growth rate from 2020 to 2021 might indeed be because of people dying of Covid, on top of a decrease in the influx of immigrants because of Trump administration policies.

Here's my headline: Population growth in most of U.S. stalls, but big cities get bigger.
